sp.p: I say, then, that when, in us living beings, harmony is broken up, a disruption of nature and a generation of pain also take place at the same moment.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What you say is very likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if harmony is recomposed and returns to its own nature, then I say that pleasure is generated, if I may speak in the fewest and briefest words about matters of the highest import.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think you are right, Socrates; but let us try to be more explicit.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is easiest to understand common and obvious examples, is it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What examples?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is hunger a kind of breaking up and a pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And eating, which is a filling up again, is a pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Thirst again is a destruction and a pain, but the filling with moisture of that which was dried up is a pleasure. Then, too, the unnatural dissolution and disintegration we experience through heat are a pain, but the natural restoration and cooling are a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the unnatural hardening of the moisture in an animal through cold is pain; but the natural course of the elements returning to their place and separating is a pleasure. See, in short, if you think it is a reasonable statement that whenever in the class of living beings, which, as I said before, arises out of the natural union of the infinite and the finite, that union is destroyed, the destruction is pain, and the passage and return of all things to their own nature is pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us accept that; for it seems to me to be true in its general lines.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we may assume this as one kind of pain and pleasure arising severally under the conditions I have described?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let that be assumed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now assume within the soul itself the anticipation of these conditions, the sweet and cheering hope of pleasant things to come, the fearful and woful expectation of painful things to come.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, indeed, this is another kind of pleasure and pain, which belongs to the soul itself, apart from the body, and arises through expectation.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are right. I think that in these two kinds, both of which are, in my opinion, pure, and not formed by mixture of pain and pleasure, the truth about pleasure will be made manifest, whether the entire class is to be desired or such desirability is rather to be attributed to some other class among those we have mentioned, whereas pleasure and pain, like heat, cold, and other such things, are sometimes desirable and sometimes undesirable, because they are not good themselves, though some of them sometimes admit on occasion the nature of the good.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are quite right in saying that we must track our quarry on this trail.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, let us agree on this point: If it is true, as we said, that destruction is pain and restoration is pleasure, let us consider the case of living beings in which neither destruction nor restoration is going on, and what their state is under such conditions. Fix your mind on my question: Must not every living being under those conditions necessarily be devoid of any feeling of pain or pleasure, great or small?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, necessarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Have we, then, a third condition, besides those of feeling pleasure and pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, do your best to bear it in mind; for remembering or forgetting it will make a great difference in our judgement of pleasure. And I should like, if you do not object, to speak briefly about it.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Pray do so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You know that there is nothing to hinder a man from living the life of wisdom in this manner.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean without feeling pleasure or pain?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, for it was said, you know, in our comparison of the lives that he who chose the life of mind and wisdom was to have no feeling of pleasure, great or small.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, surely, that was said.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Such a man, then, would have such a life; and perhaps it is not unreasonable, if that is the most divine of lives.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly it is not likely that gods feel either joy or its opposite.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, it is very unlikely; for either is unseemly for them. But let us reserve the discussion of that point for another time, if it is appropriate, and we will give mind credit for it in contending for the second place, if we cannot count it for the first.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now the other class of pleasure, which we said was an affair of the soul alone, originates entirely in memory.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must, apparently, first take up memory, and perception even before memory, if these matters are to be made clear to us properly.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Assume that some of the affections of our body are extinguished in the body before they reach the soul, leaving the soul unaffected, and that other affections permeate both body and soul and cause a vibration in both conjointly and in each individually.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us assume that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we be right in saying that the soul forgets those which do not permeate both, and does not forget those which do?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do not in the least imagine that when I speak of forgetting I mean that forgetfulness arises in this case; for forgetfulness is the departure of memory, and in the case under consideration memory has not yet come into being; now it is absurd to speak of the loss of that which does not exist and has not yet come into being, is it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then just change the terms.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Instead of saying that the soul forgets, when it is unaffected by the vibrations of the body, apply the term want of perception to that which you are now calling forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the union of soul and body in one common affection and one common motion you may properly call perception.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then do we now understand what we mean by perception?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think, then, that memory may rightly be defined as the preservation of perception.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite rightly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But do we not say that memory differs from recollection?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is this the difference?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When the soul alone by itself, apart from the body, recalls completely any experience it has had in company with the body, we say that it recollects do we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And again when the soul has lost the memory of a perception or of something it has learned and then alone by itself regains this, we call everything of that kind recollection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now my reason for saying all this is—

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That henceforth we may comprehend as completely and clearly as possible the pleasure of the soul, and likewise its desire, apart from the body; for both of these appear to be made plain by what has been said about memory and recollection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us, then, Socrates, discuss the next point.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must, it seems, consider many things in relation to the origin and general aspect of pleasure; but now I think our first task is to take up the nature and origin of desire.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then let us examine that; for we shall not lose anything.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Oh yes, Protarchus, we shall lose a great deal! When we find what we are seeking we shall lose our perplexity about these very questions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is a fair counter; but let us try to take up the next point.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Did we not say just now that hunger, thirst, and the like were desires?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: They are, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What sort of identity have we in view when we call these, which are so different, by one name?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By Zeus, Socrates, that question may not be easy to answer, yet it must be answered.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, begin again at that point with the same examples.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: At what point?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We say of a thing on any particular occasion, “its thirsty,” do we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that means being empty?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And is thirst, then, a desire?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, of drink.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Of drink, or of being filled with drink?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of being filled, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The man, then, who is empty desires, as it appears, the opposite of what he feels for, being empty, he longs to be filled.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is very plain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, is there any source from which a man who is empty at first can gain a comprehension, whether by perception or by memory, of fulness, a thing which he does not feel at the time and has never felt before?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It cannot be done.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And yet he who desires, desires something, we say.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he does not desire that which he feels; for he is thirsty, and that is emptiness, but he desires fulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then somehow some part of him who is thirsty can apprehend fulness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, obviously.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it cannot be the body, for that is empty.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The only remaining possibility is that the soul apprehends it, which it must do by means of memory; for what other means could it employ?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No other, I should say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do we understand the consequences of this argument?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are the consequences?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This argument declares that we have no bodily desire.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because it shows that the endeavor of every living being is always towards the opposite of the actual conditions of the body.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the impulse which leads towards the opposite of those conditions shows that there is a memory of the opposite of the conditions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the argument, by showing that memory is that which leads us towards the objects of desire, has proved that all the impulse, the desire, and the ruling principle in every living being are of the soul.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So the argument denies utterly that the body hungers or thirsts or has any such affection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us consider a further point in connection with those very affections. For I think the purpose of the argument is to point out to us a state of life existing in them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of what sort of life are you speaking, and in what affections does it exist?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In the affections of fulness and emptiness and all which pertain to the preservation and destruction of living beings, and I am thinking that if we fall into one of these we feel pain, which is followed by joy when we change to the other.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if a man is between the two?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How between them?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because of his condition, he is suffering, but he remembers the pleasures the coming of which would bring him an end of his pain; as yet, however, he does not possess them. Well then, shall we say that he is between the affections, or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us say so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we say that he is wholly pained or wholly pleased?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, by Zeus, but he is afflicted with a twofold pain; he suffers in body from his sensation, and in soul from expectation and longing.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How could you, Protarchus, speak of twofold pain? Is not an empty man sometimes possessed of a sure hope of being filled, and sometimes, on the contrary, quite hopeless?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do you not think that when he has a hope of being filled he takes pleasure in his memory, and yet at the same time, since he is at the moment empty, suffers pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It cannot be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: At such a time, then, a man, or any other animal, has both pain and pleasure at once.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when an empty man is without hope of being filled, what then? Is not that the time when the twofold feeling of pain would arise, which you just now observed and thought the pain simply was twofold?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us make use of our examination of those affections for a particular purpose.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: For what purpose?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we say that those pleasures and pains are true or false, or that some are true and others not so?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But, Socrates, how can there be false pleasures or pains?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, Protarchus, how can there be true and false fears, or true and false expectations, or true and false opinions?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Opinions I would grant you, but not the rest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What? I am afraid we are starting a very considerable discussion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And yet we must consider, thou son of that man,“Son of that man” may mean “son of Philebus,” in so far as Protarchus is a pupil of Philebus, or (so Bury) “son of Gorgias,” the orator and teacher (cf. Plat. Phaedo 58b), or the father of Protarchus may be referred to by the pronoun, possibly because Socrates does not at the moment recall his name or because he wishes to imply that he was a man of mark. whether the discussion is relevant to what has gone before.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We must dismiss everything else, tedious or otherwise, that is irrelevant.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now tell me; for I am always utterly amazed by the same questions we were just proposing.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are not some pleasures false and others true?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How could that be?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, as you maintain, nobody, either sleeping or waking or insane or deranged, ever thinks he feels pleasure when he does not feel it, and never, on the other hand, thinks he suffers pain when he does not suffer it?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: We have, Socrates, always believed that all this is as you suggest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But is the belief correct? Shall we consider whether it is so or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I should say we ought to consider that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us analyze still more clearly what we were just now saying about pleasure and opinion. There is a faculty of having an opinion, is there not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And of feeling pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And there is an object of opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And something by which that which feels pleasure is pleased?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which has opinion, whether right or wrong, never loses its function of really having opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And that which feels pleasure, whether rightly or wrongly, will clearly never lose its function of really feeling pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that is true, too.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we must consider how it is that opinion is both true and false and pleasure only true, though the holding of opinion and the feeling of pleasure are equally real.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, so we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean that we must consider this question because falsehood and truth are added as attributes to opinion, and thereby it becomes not merely opinion, but opinion of a certain quality in each instance?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And furthermore, we must reach an agreement on the question whether, even if some things have qualities, pleasure and pain are not merely what they are, without qualities or attributes.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Evidently we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it is easy enough to see that they have qualities. For we said a long time ago that both pains and pleasures are great and small and intense.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if badness becomes an attribute of any of these, Protarchus, shall we say that the opinion or the pleasure thereby becomes bad?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Why certainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if rightness or its opposite becomes an attribute of one of them? Shall we not say that the opinion is right, if it has rightness, and the pleasure likewise?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Obviously.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if that which is opined is mistaken, must we not agree that the opinion, since it is at the moment making a mistake, is not right or rightly opining?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And what if we see a pain or a pleasure making a mistake in respect of that by which the pain or pleasure is caused? Shall we give it the attribute of right or good or any of the words which denote excellence?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is impossible if the pleasure is mistaken.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And certainly pleasure often seems to come to us in connection with false, not true, opinion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course it does; and in such a case, Socrates, we call the opinion false; but nobody would ever call the actual pleasure false.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You are an eager advocate of the case of pleasure just now, Protarchus.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Oh no, I merely say what I hear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is there no difference, my friend, between the pleasure which is connected with right opinion and knowledge and that which often comes to each of us with falsehood and ignorance?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There is likely to be a great difference.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us proceed to the contemplation of the difference between them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Lead on as you think best.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this is the way I lead.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do we agree that there is such a thing as false opinion and also as true opinion?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And, as we were saying just now, pleasure and pain often follow them—I mean true and false opinion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do not opinion and the power of forming an opinion always come to us from memory and perception?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do we, then, believe that our relation to these faculties is somewhat as follows?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you say that often when a man sees things at a distance and not very clearly, he wishes to distinguish between the things which he sees?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I should say so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Next, then, would he not ask himself—

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: “What is that which is visible standing beside the rock under a tree?” Do you not think a man might ask himself such a question if he saw such objects presented to his view?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And after that our gazer might reply to himself correctly “It is a man”?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Or, again, perhaps he might be misled into the belief that it was a work of some shepherds, and then he would call the thing which he saw an image.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And if some one is with him, he might repeat aloud to his companion what he had said to himself, and thus that which we called an opinion now becomes a statement?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if he is alone when he has this thought, he sometimes carries it about in his mind for a long time.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, is your view about what takes place in such cases the same as mine?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is yours?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I think the soul at such a time is like a book.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Memory unites with the senses, and they and the feelings which are connected with them seem to me almost to write words in our souls; and when the feeling in question writes the truth, true opinions and true statements are produced in us; but when the writer within us writes falsehoods, the resulting opinions and statements are the opposite of true.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is my view completely, and I accept it as stated.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then accept also the presence of another workman in our souls at such a time.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What workman?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A painter, who paints in our souls pictures to illustrate the words which the writer has written.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But how do we say he does this, and when?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When a man receives from sight or some other sense the opinions and utterances of the moment and afterwards beholds in his own mind the images of those opinions and utterances. That happens to us often enough, does it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It certainly does.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the images of the true opinions are true, and those of the false are false?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if we are right about that, let us consider a further question.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whether this is an inevitable experience in relation to the present and the past, but not in relation to the future.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is in the same relation to all kinds of time.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Was it not said a while ago that the pleasures and pains which belong to the soul alone might come before the pleasures and pains of the body, so that we have the pleasure and pain of anticipation, which relate to the future?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do the writings and pictures, then, which we imagined a little while ago to exist within us, relate to the past and present, but not to the future?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To the future especially.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you say “to the future especially” because they are all hopes relating to the future and we are always filled with hopes all our lives?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, here is a further question for you to answer.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A just, pious, and good man is surely a friend of the gods, is he not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And an unjust and thoroughly bad man is the reverse?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But, as we were just now saying, every man is full of many hopes?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And there are in all of us written words which we call hopes?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And also the images painted there; and often a man sees an abundance of gold coming into his possession, and in its train many pleasures; and he even sees a picture of himself enjoying himself immensely.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Shall we or shall we not say that of these pictures those are for the most part true which are presented to the good, because they are friends of the gods, whereas those presented to the bad are for the most part false?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Surely we must say that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the bad also, no less than the good, have pleasures painted in their souls, but they are false pleasures.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, surely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the bad rejoice for the most part in the false, and the good in true pleasures.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is inevitably true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: According to our present view, then, there are false pleasures in the souls of men, imitations or caricatures of the true pleasures; and pains likewise.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There are.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We saw, you remember, that he who had an opinion at all always really had an opinion, but it was sometimes not based upon realities, whether present, past, or future.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And this it was, I believe, which created false opinion and the holding of false opinions, was it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well, must we not also grant that pleasure and pain stand in the same relation to realities?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean that he who feels pleasure at all in any way or manner always really feels pleasure, but it is sometimes not based upon realities, whether present or past, and often, perhaps most frequently, upon things which will never even be realities in the future.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: This also, Socrates, must inevitably be the case.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the same may be said of fear and anger and all that sort of thing—that they are all sometimes false?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, can we say that opinions become bad or good except as they become false?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we understand, I believe, that pleasures also are not bad except by being false.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No; you have said quite the reverse of the truth, Socrates; for no one would be at all likely to call pains and pleasures bad because they are false, but because they are involved in another great and manifold evil.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then of the evil pleasures which are such because of evil we will speak a little later, if we still care to do so; but of the false pleasures we must prove in another way that they exist and come into existence in us often and in great numbers; for this may help us to reach our decisions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, of course; that is, if such pleasures exist.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But they do exist, Protarchus, in my opinion; however, until we have established the truth of this opinion, it cannot be unquestioned.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then let us, like athletes, approach and grapple with this new argument.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us do so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We said, you may remember, a little while ago, that when desires, as they are called, exist in us, the soul is apart from the body and separate from it in feelings.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I remember; that was said.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And was not the soul that which desired the opposites of the conditions of the body and the body that which caused pleasure or pain because of feeling?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that was the case.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then draw the conclusion as to what takes place in these circumstances.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What takes place is this: in these circumstances pleasures and pains exist at the same time and the sensations of opposite pleasures and pains are present side by side simultaneously, as was made clear just now.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that is clear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And have we not also said and agreed and settled something further?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That both pleasure and pain admit of the more and less and are of the class of the infinite.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, we have said that, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what means is there of judging rightly of this?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How and in what way do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean to ask whether the purpose of our judgement of these matters in such circumstances is to recognize in each instance which of these elements is greater or smaller or more intense, comparing pain with pleasure, pain with pain, and pleasure with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly there are such differences, and that is the purpose of our judgement.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, in the case of sight, seeing things from too near at hand or from too great a distance obscures their real sizes and causes us to have false opinions; and does not this same thing happen in the case of pains and pleasures?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, Socrates, even much more than in the case of sight.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then our present conclusion is the opposite of what we said a little while ago.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: To what do you refer?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A while ago these opinions, being false or true, imbued the pains and pleasures with their own condition of truth or falsehood.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But now, because they are seen at various and changing distances and are compared with one another, the pleasures themselves appear greater and more intense by comparison with the pains, and the pains in turn, through comparison with the pleasures, vary inversely as they.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is inevitable for the reasons you have given.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: They both, then, appear greater and less than the reality. Now if you abstract from both of them this apparent, but unreal, excess or inferiority, you cannot say that its appearance is true, nor again can you have the face to affirm that the part of pleasure or pain which corresponds to this is true or real.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, I cannot.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Next, then, we will see whether we may not in another direction come upon pleasures and pains still more false than these appearing and existing in living beings.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What pleasures and what method do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It has been said many times that pains and woes and aches and everything that is called by names of that sort are caused when nature in any instance is corrupted through combinations and dissolutions, fillings and emptyings, increases and diminutions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that has been said many times.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we agreed that when things are restored to their natural condition, that restoration is pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But when neither of these changes takes place in the body, what then?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: When could that be the case, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That question of yours is not to the point, Protarchus.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Because you do not prevent my asking my own question again.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What question?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Why, Protarchus, I may say, granting that such a condition does not arise, what would be the necessary result if it did?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean if the body is not changed in either direction?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is clear, Socrates, that in that case there would never be either pleasure or pain.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Excellent. But you believe, I fancy, that some such change must always be taking place in us, as the philosophersHeracleitus and his followers. say; for all things are always flowing and shifting.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that is what they say, and I think their theory is important.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Of course it is, in view of their own importance. But I should like to avoid this argument which is rushing at us. I am going to run away; come along and escape with me.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is your way of escape?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: “We grant you all this” let us say to them. But answer me this, Protarchus, are we and all other living beings always conscious of everything that happens to us of our growth and all that sort of thing—or is the truth quite the reverse of that?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite the reverse, surely; for we are almost entirely unconscious of everything of that sort.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we were not right in saying just now that the fluctuations and changes cause pains and pleasures.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: A better and more unassailable statement would be this.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That the great changes cause pains and pleasures in us, but the moderate and small ones cause no pains or pleasures at all.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is more correct than the other statement, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But if that is the case, the life of which we spoke just now would come back again.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What life?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The life which we said was painless and without joys.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, therefore, assume three lives, one pleasant, one painful, and one neither of the two; or do you disagree?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, I agree to this, that there are the three lives.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then freedom from pain would not be identical with pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: When you hear anyone say that the pleasantest of all things is to live all ones life without pain, what do you understand him to mean?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think he means that freedom from pain is pleasure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now let us assume that we have three things; no matter what they are, but let us use fine names and call one gold, another silver, and the third neither of the two.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now can that which is neither become either gold or silver?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Neither can that middle life of which we spoke ever be rightly considered in opinion or called in speech pleasant or painful, at any rate by those who reason correctly.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, certainly not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But surely, my friend, we are aware of persons who call it and consider it so.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do they, then, think they feel pleasure whenever they are not in pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is what they say.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then they do think they feel pleasure at such times; for otherwise they would not say so.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Most likely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Certainly, then, they have a false opinion about pleasure, if there is an essential difference between feeling pleasure and not feeling pain.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: And we certainly found that difference.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then shall we adopt the view that there are, as we said just now, three states, or that there are only two—pain, which is an evil to mankind, and freedom from pain, which is of itself a good and is called pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Why do we ask ourselves that question now, Socrates? I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, Protarchus, for you certainly do not understand about the enemies of our friend Philebus.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Certain men who are said to be master thinkers about nature, and who deny the existence of pleasures altogether.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: They say that what Philebus and his school call pleasures are all merely refuges from pain.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Do you recommend that we adopt their view, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: No, but that we make use of them as seers who divine the truth, not by acquired skill, but by some innate and not ignoble repugnance which makes them hate the power of pleasure and think it so utterly unsound that its very attractiveness is mere trickery, not pleasure. You may make use of them in this way, considering also their other expressions of dislike; and after that you shall learn of the pleasures which seem to me to be true, in order that we may consider the power of pleasure from both points of view and form our judgement by comparing them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, consider these men as allies and follow them in the track of their dislike. I fancy their method would be to begin somewhere further back and ask whether, if we wished to discover the nature of any class—take the hard, for instance—we should be more likely to learn it by looking at the hardest things or at the least hard. Now you, Protarchus, must reply to them as you have been replying to me.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By all means, and I say to them that we should look at the greatest things.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if we wished to discover what the nature of pleasure is, we should look, not at the smallest pleasures, but at those which are considered most extreme and intense.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Every one would agree to that now.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And the commonest and greatest pleasures are, as we have often said, those connected with the body, are they not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are they greater, then, and do they become greater in those who are ill or in those who are in health? Let us take care not to answer hastily and fall into error. Perhaps we might say they are greater in those who are in health.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is reasonable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, but are not those pleasures the greatest which gratify the greatest desires?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But do not people who are in a fever, or in similar diseases, feel more intensely thirst and cold and other bodily sufferings which they usually have; and do they not feel greater want, followed by greater pleasure when their want is satisfied? Is this true, or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Now that you have said it, it certainly appears to be true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then should we appear to be right in saying that if we wished to discover the greatest pleasures we should have to look, not at health, but at disease? Now do not imagine that I mean to ask you whether those who are very ill have more pleasures than those who are well, but assume that I am asking about the greatness of pleasure, and where the greatest intensity of such feeling normally occurs. For we say that it is our task to discover the nature of pleasure and what those who deny its existence altogether say that it is.This paradox means “what those say it is who deny that it is really pleasure.”

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think I understand you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Presently, Protarchus, you will show that more clearly, for I want you to answer a question. Do you see greater pleasures—I do not mean greater in number, but greater in intensity and degree—in riotous living or in a life of self-restraint? Be careful about your reply.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand you, and I see that there is a great difference. For the self-restrained are always held in check by the advice of the proverbial expression “nothing too much,” which guides their actions; but intense pleasure holds sway over the foolish and dissolute even to the point of madness and makes them notorious.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Good; and if that is true, it is clear that the greatest pleasures and the greatest pains originate in some depravity of soul and body, not in virtue.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we must select some of these pleasures and see what there is about them which made us say that they are the greatest.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, we must.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now see what there is about the pleasures which are related to certain diseases.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What diseases?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Repulsive diseases which the philosophers of dislike whom we mentioned utterly abominate.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are the pleasures?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For instance, the relief of the itch and the like by scratching, no other treatment being required. For in Heavens name what shall we say the feeling is which we have in this case? Is it pleasure or pain?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think, Socrates, it is a mixed evil.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I did not introduce this question on Philebus account; but unless we consider these pleasures and those that follow in their train, Protarchus, we can probably never settle the point at issue.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then we must attack this family of pleasures.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: You mean those which are mixed?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Some mixtures are concerned with the body and are in the body only, and some belong only to the soul and are in the soul; and we shall also find some mingled pains and pleasures belonging both to the soul and to the body, and these are sometimes called pleasures, sometimes pains.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Whenever, in the process of restoration or destruction, anyone has two opposite feelings, as we sometimes are cold, but are growing warm, or are hot, but are growing cold, the desire of having the one and being free from the other, the mixture of bitter and sweet, as they say, joined with the difficulty in getting rid of the bitter, produces impatience and, later, wild excitement.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What you say is perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And such mixtures sometimes consist of equal pains and pleasures and sometimes contain more of one or the other, do they not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In the case of the mixtures in which the pains are more than the pleasures—say the itch, which we mentioned just now, or tickling—when the burning inflammation is within and is not reached by the rubbing and scratching, which separate only such mixtures as are on the surface, sometimes by bringing the affected parts to the fire or to something cold we change from wretchedness to inexpressible pleasures, and sometimes the opposition between the internal and the external produces a mixture of pains and pleasures, whichever happens to preponderate; this is the result of the forcible separation of combined elements, or the combination of those that were separate, and the concomitant juxtaposition of pains and pleasures.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And when the pleasure is the predominant element in the mixture, the slight tincture of pain tickles a man and makes him mildly impatient, or again an excessive proportion of pleasure excites him and sometimes even makes him leap for joy; it produces in him all sorts of colors, attitudes, and paintings, and even causes great amazement and foolish shouting, does it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And it makes him say of himself, and others say of him, that he is pleased to death with these delights, and the more unrestrained and foolish he is, the more he always gives himself up to the pursuit of these pleasures; he calls them the greatest of all things and counts that man the happiest who lives most entirely in the enjoyment of them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Socrates, you have described admirably what happens in the case of most people.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
That may be, Protarchus, so far as concerns purely bodily pleasures in which internal and external sensations unite; but concerning the pleasures in which the soul and the body contribute opposite elements, each adding pain or pleasure to the others pleasure or pain, so that both unite in a single mixture—concerning these I said before that when a man is empty he desires to be filled, and rejoices in his expectation, but is pained by his emptiness, and now I add, what I did not say at that time, that in all these cases, which are innumerable,
of opposition between soul and body, there is one single mixture of pain and pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I believe you are quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: One further mixture of pain and pleasure is left.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That mixture of its own feelings which we said the soul often experiences.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: And what do we call this

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Do you not regard anger, fear, yearning, mourning, love, jealousy, envy, and the like as pains of the soul and the soul only?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p:
And shall we not find them full of ineffable pleasures? Or must I remind you of the anger?
Which stirs a man, though very wise, to wrath,
And sweeter is than honey from the comb,unknown and of the pleasures mixed with pains, which we find in mournings and longings?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, you need not remind me; those things occur just as you suggest.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And you remember, too, how people enjoy weeping at tragedies?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And are you aware of the condition of the soul at comedies, how there also we have a mixture of pain and pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I do not quite understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Indeed it is by no means easy, Protarchus, to understand such a condition under those circumstances.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No at least I do not find it so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, let us take this under consideration, all the more because of its obscurity; then we can more readily understand the mixture of pain and pleasure in other cases.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Please go on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Would you say that envy, which was mentioned just now, was a pain of the soul, or not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I say it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But certainly we see the envious man rejoicing in the misfortunes of his neighbors.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, very much so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Surely ignorance is an evil, as is also what we call stupidity.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Surely.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Next, then, consider the nature of the ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The ridiculous is in its main aspect a kind of vice which gives its name to a condition; and it is that part of vice in general which involves the opposite of the condition mentioned in the inscription at Delphi.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You mean “Know thyself,” Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes; and the opposite of that, in the language of the inscription, would evidently be not to know oneself at all.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Protarchus, try to divide this into three.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How do you mean? I am afraid I can never do it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then you say that I must now make the division?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I say so, and I beg you to do so, besides.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Must not all those who do not know themselves be affected by their condition in one of three ways?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First in regard to wealth; such a man thinks he is richer than he is.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly a good many are affected in that way.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And there are still more who think they are taller and handsomer than they are and that they possess better physical qualities in general than is the case.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But by far the greatest number, I fancy, err in the third way, about the qualities of, the soul, thinking that they excel in virtue when they do not.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, most decidedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And of all the virtues, is not wisdom the one to which people in general lay claim, thereby filling themselves with strife and false conceit of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we should surely be right in calling all that an evil condition.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then this must further be divided into two parts, if we are to gain insight into childish envy with its absurd mixture of pleasure and pain. “How shall we divide it,” do you say? All who have this false and foolish conceit of themselves fall, like the rest of mankind, into two classes: some necessarily have strength and power, others, as I believe, the reverse.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, necessarily.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Make the division, then, on that principle; those of them who have this false conceit and are weak and unable to revenge themselves when they are laughed at you may truly call ridiculous, but those who are strong and able to revenge themselves you will define most correctly to yourself by calling them powerful, terrible, and hateful, for ignorance in the powerful is hateful and infamous—since whether real or feigned it injures their neighbors—but ignorance in the weak appears to us as naturally ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right. But the mixture of pleasure and pain in all this is not yet clear to me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: First, then, take up the nature of envy.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is envy a kind of unrighteous pain and also a pleasure?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Undoubtedly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But it is neither wrong nor envious to rejoice in the misfortunes of our enemies, is it?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But when people sometimes see the misfortunes of their friends and rejoice instead of grieving, is not that wrong?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we said that ignorance was an evil to every one, did we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then the false conceits of our friends concerning their wisdom, their beauty, and their other qualities which we mentioned just now, saying that they belong to three classes, are ridiculous when they are weak, but hateful when they are powerful. Shall we, or shall we not, affirm that, as I said just now, this state of mind when possessed in its harmless form by any of our friends, is ridiculous in the eyes of others?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly it is ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do we not agree that ignorance is in itself a misfortune?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, a great one.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And do we feel pleasure or pain when we laugh at it?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Pleasure, evidently.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Did we not say that pleasure in the misfortunes of friends was caused by envy?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: There can be no other cause.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then our argument declares that when we laugh at the ridiculous qualities of our friends, we mix pleasure with pain, since we mix it with envy; for we have agreed all along that envy is a pain of the soul, and that laughter is a pleasure, yet these two are present at the same time on such occasions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So now our argument shows that in mournings and tragedies and comedies, not merely on the stage, but in all the tragedy and comedy of life, and in countless other ways, pain is mixed with pleasure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is impossible not to agree with that, Socrates, even though one be most eager to maintain the opposite opinion.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Again we mentioned anger, yearning, mourning, love, jealousy, envy, and the like, as conditions in which we should find a mixture of the two elements we have now often named, did we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we understand that all the details I have been describing just now are concerned only with sorrow and envy and anger?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course we understand that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then there are still many others of those conditions left for us to discuss.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, very many.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now why do you particularly suppose I pointed out to you the mixture of pain and pleasure in comedy? Was it not for the sake of convincing you, because it is easy to show the mixture in love and fear and the rest, and because I thought that when you had made this example your own, you would relieve me from the necessity of discussing those other conditions in detail, and would simply accept the fact that in the affections of the body apart from the soul, of the soul apart from the body, and of the two in common, there are plentiful mixtures of pain and pleasure? So tell me; will you let me off, or will you keep on till midnight? But I think I need say only a few words to induce you to let me off. I will agree to give you an account of all these matters tomorrow, but now I wish to steer my bark towards the remaining points that are needful for the judgement which Philebus demands.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Good, Socrates; just finish what remains in any way you please.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then after the mixed pleasures we should naturally and almost of necessity proceed in turn to the unmixed.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: So I will turn to them and try to explain them; for I do not in the least agree with those who say that all pleasures are merely surcease from pain, but, as I said, I use them as witnesses to prove that some pleasures are apparent, but not in any way real, and that there are others which appear to be both great and numerous, but are really mixed up with pains and with cessations of the greatest pains and distresses of body and soul.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But what pleasures, Socrates, may rightly be considered true?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Those arising from what are called beautiful colors, or from forms, most of those that arise from odors and sounds, in short all those the want of which is unfelt and painless, whereas the satisfaction furnished by them is felt by the senses, pleasant, and unmixed with pain.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Once more, Socrates, what do you mean by this?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My meaning is certainly not clear at the first glance, and I must try to make it so. For when I say beauty of form, I am trying to express, not what most people would understand by the words, such as the beauty of animals or of paintings, but I mean, says the argument, the straight line and the circle and the plane and solid figures formed from these by turning-lathes and rulers and patterns of angles; perhaps you understand. For I assert that the beauty of these is not relative, like that of other things, but they are always absolutely beautiful by nature and have peculiar pleasures in no way subject to comparison with the pleasures of scratching; and there are colors which possess beauty and pleasures of this character. Do you understand?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I am trying to do so, Socrates; and I hope you also will try to make your meaning still clearer.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I mean that those sounds which are smooth and clear and send forth a single pure note are beautiful, not relatively, but absolutely, and that there are pleasures which pertain to these by nature and result from them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, that also is true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The pleasures of smell are a less divine class; but they have no necessary pains mixed with them, and wherever and in whatever we find this freedom from pain, I regard it always as a mark of similarity to those other pleasures. These, then, are two classes of the pleasures of which I am speaking. Do you understand me?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And further let us add to these the pleasures of knowledge, if they appear to us not to have hunger for knowledge or pangs of such hunger as their source.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I agree to that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, if men are full of knowledge and then lose it through forgetfulness, do you see any pains in the losses?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Not by their inherent nature, but sometimes there is pain in reflecting on the event, when a man who has lost knowledge is pained by the lack of it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: True, my dear fellow, but just at present we are recounting natural feelings only, not reflection.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then you are right in saying that we feel no pain in the loss of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we may say that these pleasures of knowledge are unmixed with pain and are felt not by the many but only by very few.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And now that we have fairly well separated the pure pleasures and those which may be pretty correctly called impure, let us add the further statement that the intense pleasures are without measure and those of the opposite sort have measure; those which admit of greatness and intensity and are often or seldom great or intense we shall assign to the class of the infinite, which circulates more or less freely through the body and soul alike, and the others we shall assign to the class of the limited.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There is still another question about them to be considered.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: What kind of thing is most closely related to truth? The pure and unadulterated, or the violent, the widespread, the great, and the sufficient?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is your object, Socrates, in asking that question?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My object, Protarchus, is to leave no gap in my test of pleasure and knowledge, if some part of each of them is pure and some part impure, in order that each of them may offer itself for judgement in a condition of purity, and thus make the judgement easier for you and me and all our audience.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Very well, let us adopt that point of view towards all the classes which we call pure. First let us select one of them and examine it.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Which shall we select?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us first, if agreeable to you, consider whiteness.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How can we have purity in whiteness, and what purity? Is it the greatest and most widespread, or the most unmixed, that in which there is no trace of any other color?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Clearly it is the most unadulterated.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Right. Shall we not, then, Protarchus, declare that this, and not the most numerous or the greatest, is both the truest and the most beautiful of all whitenesses?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we shall be perfectly right in saying that a little pure white is whiter and more beautiful and truer than a great deal of mixed white.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well then, we shall have no need of many such examples in our discussion of pleasure; we see well enough from this one that any pleasure, however small or infrequent, if uncontaminated with pain, is pleasanter and more beautiful than a great or often repeated pleasure without purity.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Most certainly; and the example is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Here is another point. Have we not often heard it said of pleasure that it is always a process or generation and that there is no state or existence of pleasure? There are some clever people who try to prove this theory to us, and we ought to be grateful to them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I will explain this whole matter, Protarchus, by asking questions.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Go on; ask your questions.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There are two parts of existence, the one self-existent, the other always desiring something else.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What do you mean? What are these two?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The one is by nature more imposing, the other inferior.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Speak still more plainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We have seen beloved boys who are fair and good, and brave lovers of them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Try to find another pair like these in all the relations we are speaking of.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Must I say it a third time? Please tell your meaning more plainly, Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is no riddle, Protarchus; the talk is merely jesting with us and means that one part of existences always exists for the sake of something, and the other part is that for the sake of which the former is always coming into being.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I can hardly understand after all your repetition.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Perhaps, my boy, you will understand better as the discussion proceeds.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us take another pair.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: One is the generation of all things (the process of coming into being), the other is existence or being.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I accept your two, generation and being.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Quite right. Now which of these shall we say is for the sake of the other, generation for the sake of being, or being for the sake of generation?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are now asking whether that which is called being is what it is for the sake of generation?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, plainly.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: For Heavens sake, is this the kind of question you keep asking me, “Tell me, Protarchus, whether you think shipbuilding is for the sake of ships, or ships for the sake of shipbuilding,” and all that sort of thing?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes; that is just what I mean, Protarchus.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Then why did you not answer it yourself, Socrates?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: There is no reason why I should not; but I want you to take part in the discussion.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: I say that drugs and all sorts of instruments and materials are always employed for the sake of production or generation, but that every instance of generation is for the sake of some being or other, and generation in general is for the sake of being in general.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is very clear.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then pleasure, if it is a form of generation, would be generated for the sake of some form of being.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now surely that for the sake of which anything is generated is in the class of the good, and that which is generated for the sake of something else, my friend, must be placed in another class.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Most undeniably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then if pleasure is a form of generation, we shall be right in placing it in a class other than that of the good, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then, as I said when we began to discuss this point, we ought to be grateful to him who pointed out that there is only a generation, but no existence, of pleasure; for he is clearly making a laughing-stock of those who assert that pleasure is a good.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, most emphatically.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he will also surely make a laughing-stock of all those who find their highest end in forms of generation.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How is that, and to whom do you refer?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: To those who, when cured of hunger or thirst or any of the troubles which are cured by generation are pleased because of the generation, as if it were pleasure, and say that they would not wish to live without thirst and hunger and the like, if they could not experience the feelings which follow after them.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That seems to be their view.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We should all agree that the opposite of generation is destruction, should we not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Inevitably.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And he who chooses as they do would be choosing destruction and generation, not that third life in which there was neither pleasure nor pain, but only the purest possible thought.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is a great absurdity, as it appears, Socrates, to tell us that pleasure is a good.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Yes, a great absurdity, and let us go still further.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is it not absurd to say that there is nothing good in the body or many other things, but only in the soul, and that in the soul the only good is pleasure, and that courage and self-restraint and understanding and all the other good things of the soul are nothing of the sort; and beyond all this to be obliged to say that he who is not feeling pleasure, and is feeling pain, is bad when he feels pain, though he be the best of men, and that he who feels pleasure is, when he feels pleasure, the more excellent in virtue the greater the pleasure he feels?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: All that, Socrates, is the height of absurdity.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Now let us not undertake to subject pleasure to every possible test and then be found to give mind and knowledge very gentle treatment. Let us rather strike them boldly everywhere to see if their metal rings unsound at any point; so we shall find out what is by nature purest in them, and then we can make use of the truest elements of these and of pleasure to form our judgement of both.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, then, one part of knowledge is productive, the other has to do with education and support. Is that true?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us first consider whether in the manual arts one part is more allied to knowledge, and the other less, and the one should be regarded as purest, the other as less pure.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, we ought to consider that.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And should the ruling elements of each of them be separated and distinguished from the rest?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What are they, and how can they be separated?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: For example, if arithmetic and the sciences of measurement and weighing were taken away from all arts, what was left of any of them would be, so to speak, pretty worthless.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, pretty worthless.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: All that would be left for us would be to conjecture and to drill the perceptions by practice and experience, with the additional use of the powers of guessing, which are commonly called arts and acquire their efficacy by practice and toil.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is undeniable.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Take music first; it is full of this; it attains harmony by guesswork based on practice, not by measurement; and flute music throughout tries to find the pitch of each note as it is produced by guess, so that the amount of uncertainty mixed up in it is great, and the amount of certainty small.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And we shall find that medicine and agriculture and piloting and generalship are all in the same case.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the art of building, I believe, employs the greatest number of measures and instruments which give it great accuracy and make it more scientific than most arts.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In shipbuilding and house-building, and many other branches of wood-working. For the artisan uses a rule, I imagine, a lathe, compasses, a chalk-line, and an ingenious instrument called a vice.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly, Socrates; you are right.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Let us, then, divide the arts, as they are called, into two kinds, those which resemble music, and have less accuracy in their works, and those which, like building, are more exact.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And of these the most exact are the arts which I just now mentioned first.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I think you mean arithmetic and the other arts you mentioned with it just now.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Certainly. But, Protarchus, ought not these to be divided into two kinds? What do you say?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What kinds?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are there not two kinds of arithmetic, that of the people and that of philosophers?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: How can one kind of arithmetic be distinguished from the other?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: The distinction is no small one, Protarchus. For some arithmeticians reckon unequal units, for instance, two armies and two oxen and two very small or incomparably large units; whereas others refuse to agree with them unless each of countless units is declared to differ not at all from each and every other unit.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: You are certainly quite right in saying that there is a great difference between the devotees of arithmetic, so it is reasonable to assume that it is of two kinds.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And how about the arts of reckoning and measuring as they are used in building and in trade when compared with philosophical geometry and elaborate computations—shall we speak of each of these as one or as two?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: On the analogy of the previous example, I should say that each of them was two.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Right. But do you understand why I introduced this subject?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perhaps; but I wish you would give the answer to your question.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: This discussion of ours is now, I think, no less than when we began it, seeking a counterpart of pleasure, and therefore it has introduced the present subject and is considering whether there is one kind of knowledge purer than another, as one pleasure is purer than another.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: That is very clear; it was evidently introduced with that object.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, had not the discussion already found in what preceded that the various arts had various purposes and various degrees of exactness?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And after having given an art a single name in what has preceded, thereby making us think that it was a single art, does not the discussion now assume that the same art is two and ask whether the art of the philosophers or that of the non-philosophers possesses the higher degree of clearness and purity?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, I think that is just the question it asks.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then what reply shall we make, Protarchus?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Socrates, we have found a marvelously great difference in the clearness of different kinds of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That will make the reply easier, will it not?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, to be sure; and let our reply be this, that the arithmetical and metrical arts far surpass the others and that of these the arts which are stirred by the impulse of the true philosophers are immeasurably superior in accuracy and truth about measures and numbers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: We accept that as our judgement, and relying upon you we make this confident reply to those who are clever in straining arguments—

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What reply?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: That there are two arts of arithmetic and two of measuring, and many other arts which, like these, are twofold in this way, but possess a single name in common.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Let us give this answer, Socrates, to those who you say are clever; I hope we shall have luck with it.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: These, then, we say, are the most exact arts or sciences?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: But the art of dialectic would spurn us, Protarchus, if we should judge that any other art is preferable to her.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: But what is the art to which this name belongs?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Clearly anybody can recognize the art I mean; for I am confident that all men who have any intellect whatsoever believe that the knowledge which has to do with being, reality, and eternal immutability is the truest kind of knowledge. What do you think, Protarchus?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I have often heard Gorgias constantly maintain that the art of persuasion surpasses all others for this, he said, makes all things subject to itself, not by force, but by their free will, and is by far the best of all arts; so now I hardly like to oppose either him or you.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It seems to me that you wanted to speak and threw down your arms out of modesty.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Very well; have it as you like.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Is it my fault that you have misunderstood?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Misunderstood what?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: My question, dear Protarchus, was not as yet what art or science surpasses all others by being the greatest and best and most useful to us: what I am trying to find out at present is which art, however little and of little use, has the greatest regard for clearness, exactness, and truth. See; you will not make Gorgias angry if you grant that his art is superior for the practical needs of men, but say that the study of which I spoke is superior in the matter of the most perfect truth, just as I said in speaking about the white that if it was small and pure it was superior to that which was great but impure. Now, therefore, with careful thought and due consideration, paying attention neither to the usefulness nor to the reputation of any arts or sciences, but to that faculty of our souls, if such there be, which by its nature loves the truth and does all things for the sake of the truth, let us examine this faculty and say whether it is most likely to possess mind and intelligence in the greatest purity, or we must look for some other faculty which has more valid claims.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: I am considering, and I think it is difficult to concede that any other science or art cleaves more closely to truth than this.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In saying that, did you bear in mind that the arts in general, and the men who devote themselves to them, make use of opinion and persistently investigate things which have to do with opinion? And even if they think they are studying nature, they are spending their lives in the study of the things of this world, the manner of their production, their action, and the forces to which they are subjected. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Such thinkers, then, toil to discover, not eternal verities, but transient productions of the present, the future, or the past?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And can we say that any of these things becomes certain, if tested by the touchstone of strictest truth, since none of them ever was, will be, or is in the same state?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: How can we gain anything fixed whatsoever about things which have no fixedness whatsoever?

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: In no way, as it seems to me.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then no mind or science which is occupied with them possesses the most perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: No, it naturally does not.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Then we must dismiss the thought of you and me and Gorgias and Philebus, and make this solemn declaration on the part of our argument.

sp.speaker: Protarchus
sp.p: What is the solemn declaration?
